conclusion: Analyze the image based on the direction of the arrows and the layout of the baffles.
Liquid starts at points A, B, C, and D, each with an initial downward trajectory as indicated by the arrows.
A (orange) is on the left side.
B (white) is near the center-left.
C (pink) is slightly to the right of center.
D (yellow) is on the right side.
The baffles are angled structures that will redirect the liquid's path based on their orientation.
The first set of baffles (green, cyan, white) are positioned diagonally across the board.
The final structures (red for E, cyan for F) at the bottom appear to be the containers, with their openings facing upward.
A (orange) starts on the left and moves downward, encounters the pink baffle (C) and is likely deflected rightward due to the angle.
A may then hit the green baffle and continue downward, potentially aligning with the red container (E) on the left.
B (white) starts near the center-left and moves downward, likely hits the pink baffle and is deflected rightward.
B may then interact with the white baffle and continue downward, possibly aligning with the red container (E).
C (pink) starts slightly right of center and moves downward, hits the green baffle and is deflected leftward.
C may then interact with the cyan baffle and continue downward, potentially aligning with the cyan container (F) on the right.
D (yellow) starts on the right and moves downward, likely hits the white baffle and is deflected leftward.
D may then interact with the cyan baffle and continue downward, aligning with the cyan container (F).
The red container (E) is on the left side, and the cyan container (F) is on the right side.
A and B, after multiple deflections, seem to trend toward the left side, suggesting they will flow into E.
C and D, after deflections, seem to trend toward the right side, suggesting they will flow into F.
The baffles create a balanced split, with A and B favoring E, and C and D favoring F.
